fields.headline: Ballack warns as Germany face qualification pitfalls
fields.bodyText: Germany's captain Michael Ballack has told his team-mates they must put their feet back on the ground in the Gottlieb-Daimler Stadium against the Republic of Ireland today in their opening qualifier for Euro 2008. "Some of the players have to be brought down from the clouds they've been sitting on since the wonderful World Cup," said the Chelsea midfielder. "It's time to get back to reality." Germany are still riding the euphoria of unexpectedly having reached the semi- finals at this year's World Cup when millions of fans enjoyed a month-long party in public viewing areas across the country. As hosts, Germany were seeded direct to the World Cup finals. But now they must earn their right to a place in Austria and Switzerland in two years' time. Ballack added: "We have many young players who have never played a qualifying campaign. Qualifying is something very different from a World Cup at home. That was a gift to us. Now, we have to keep our feet firmly on the ground. The alternative is a nasty surprise." Jürgen Klinsmann stepped down as national coach after Germany finished third at the World Cup, leaving the team in the care of his erstwhile assistant Joachim Löw. He led Germany to a 3-0 rout of Sweden on his debut last month. When he took over, Löw said his goal was to win Euro 2008 but Ballack warns against complacency. "Qualifying will be hard enough," he said. "Away games against Slovakia, Wales or Ireland are not going to be a piece of cake. Once we have achieved that goal, only then can we say we want to win the title. I am sure we can qualify but this is football and you never know what can happen." Ballack, who missed the game against Sweden because of a hip injury, is likely to take up a defensive midfield position similar to his World Cup role. But Per Mertesacker and Christoph Metzelder, the two central defenders, are injured so Germany's shaky and inexperienced defence has had to be reshuffled. Arsenal's goalkeeper Jens Lehmann also warned: "There are some very good players in the Ireland squad. It's going to be anything but easy." But his team-mates hope Stuttgart will again prove a lucky stadium. It was there that Germany beat Portugal 3-1 in the third-place play-off at the World Cup. AP
